instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.
definitions.CHGR_PHASE: What is CHGR_PHASE? CHGR_PHASE is charger voltage chopped up into individual slices prior to smoothing where it becomes PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC: What is SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC? SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC is a voltage that is created if SMC_BC_ACOK & PP3V42_G3H are both present that powers the chipset for the onewire circuit that allows the SMC to talk to the charger on the SYS_ONEWIRE line. This is necessary for the magsafe charger to have a light on it. .
definitions.PP3V43_G3H: What is PP3V43_G3H? This is a typo of PP3V42_G3H When you see PP3V43_G3H, assume they meant to type PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
system will not power on no green light. i replaced <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR> and on occasion will get a very quick green light when re-plugging charger.

I connected a power supply to <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> sent its voltage and system powers on.
i can see <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is getting its proper vdd, vddp,<SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> and acin voltages.
acock only outputs 1.2v, <SIGNAL>CHGR_UGATE</SIGNAL> 1.3v, <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL> 0.028v

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You need to have <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> before you can get <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL>. <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is needed to get <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> though, as it needs to open the <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> gate.

Resistance to ground in Ohm on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>? <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> OK? <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_OR_PBUS</SIGNAL> voltage?

Looking good around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> was shorted replaced it now i have <SIGNAL>PP3V43_G3H</SIGNAL> BUT! <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is fluctuating between 3.2-3.4v on <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> can't be shorted, its supposed to be 1Ohm. (Its basically a cheap fuse and also part of an RC filter). I assume you meant broken?

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stable or also pulsing? If so, is it hitting (or getting very close to) its expected voltage of 12.6V?

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Resistance to GND on 3V42? I'm smelling a dead MCP

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable at 12.57v
no pulsing 0v on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
resistance to ground on 3v42 is 0ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Alright so lets activate the brain, 0Ohm to ground on 3V42 does not sound right

Inject voltage and find whats shorting out

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: It is impossible to have PPBUS at 12.6V and a short on 3V42.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
re measured

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.280v
no pulsing 0v on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
resistance to ground on 3v42 is 0ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This is all not making sense anymore and I bet something got fried. I have no idea what you did. You can inject 3V on 3V42 rail and see what heats up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
all i did was replace 6905 and ultrasonic it after. the first measurements i gave were from the wrong board since im working on two of the same model machines. the machine is getting its 3v42 voltage and i get a green light <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_OR_PBUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_OR_PBUS_R</SIGNAL> are not stable and fluctuate from 16v to 16.30v.

<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL> also pulse from 3v to 3.4v

just to clarify <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable my explanation on post 3 was incorrect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Resistance to GND on 3V42? Corrosion around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Resistance to GND on 3v42= 2.7 kohm
No corrosion around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
just realised it wont turn on when using the apple charger but when i use a power supply i get a fan spin and shuts down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 2.7Kohm is way too low, dead MCP is highly likely.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
just realized it wont turn on when using the apple charger but when i use a power supply i get a fan spin and shuts down it takes some disconnecting and reconnecting of the power for it to stay at .26 amps and then it will turn on sometimes it stays on with no problems other times it shuts itself off.

bad mcp then?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: No idea about that specific behavior, but 2.7K on 3V42 is usually a dead MCP. Too much of a risk to waste time on this 8 year old crap then.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hmm well after fidling with the power on and off it stopped turning on but now i have a stable ppbus dcin and acok voltage. resistance to ground on 3v42 is 8.25kohm and i have a 3v s5 state and a 5v s5 only outputting 4.2v maybe something causing the voltage pulsing finally burned out?

update:wow i just realized <CAPACITOR>C7291</CAPACITOR> is missing from the board.. was this thing powering on without it? Is that even possible?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Missing <CAPACITOR>C7291</CAPACITOR> can cause this, but it also means someone decided it had to be gone. Place it back and keep your eyes open for other pulled components.

The system might be able to start without <CAPACITOR>C7291</CAPACITOR> but <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL> will have a considerable amount of ripple and inaccuracies making the system unstable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <CAPACITOR>C7291</CAPACITOR> won't matter at all. For me this thing has a dead MCP and is done, case closed time waster.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no sysonewire/<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok, thanks for the help guys ill move on.
